document.docOrigin: A Monograph of the Nematodes of the Super-family Dorylaimoidea, M. Nijhoff

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A Monograph of the Nematodes of the Super-family Dorylaimoidea

document.paragraph: The generic identity of this specics is problematical. The presence of a gubernaculum indicates a possible nygoiaimoid relationship.
Habitai: Soil, Island of Alfsburg, Germany.

Tylencholaiminae. Spear lineate with very short aperture, extensions well developed, rod-like or broadly flanged. Guiding ring double, cuticularized. Enlarged portion of esophagus somewhat shortened, with two conspicuous ventrosubmedian gland nuclei locatcd ràther far forward. Ovaries two in ail known species. Ventromedian suppléments seven or more, generally rather closely approximated.
Type species: Enchodelus macrodorus (de Man, 1880). n. comb.
Synonym: Dorylaimus macrodorus de M an, 1880.
Diagnosis: Tylencholaiminae with the above general descriptions. Distinctive because of the lineate spear with its short aperture and well developed, rod-like or broadly flanged extensions.

After publication of the Dorylaimus monograph (158) the writer found three spécimens of Dorylaimellus virginianus Cobb, taken from near the type locality. It was immediately obvions thar the several species of long speared Dorylaimus, assigned to Dorylaimellus in the monograph, did nor belong there at ail. Accordingly the genus Enchodelus is here establùhed to reçoive this very distinctive group of nemas.
The position of Enchodelus in the Dorylaimidae sériés should doubtless be locatcd immediately after Pungentus to which the members appear to be most closely related.

Nemas of the genus Enchodelus apparently feed entirely on plants. Frequently specimens are found filled with chlorophyll-like material, indicating that they had been feeding on the mosses among which they were collected.

document.paragraph: Body tapering gradually both ways from near middlc. Neck convex-conoid near lips, nairowing rapidly until lip région is only about half as wide as neck opposite spear base. Catide marked by minute transverse striac; fine radial striae visible, cspecially on taii. Latéral cords narrow, rarely wider than twice curicle width at mid-body. Latéral pores in two Unes. Amphids escutcheon shaped, apertures almost encompassing lips. Sensillae apparcntly dorylaimoid, located about opposite spear guiding ring. Lips low, obscure, completely amalgamated. Vestibule and pharynx surrounded by thick muscular bundlc. Spear massive, tripartite, flanged, occupying about one-fourth neck length. Guiding ring double. Esophagus suddcnly enlarged slightly anterior to middle. Esophagcal gland nuclei three; one dorsal, two submedian. Cardia elongatc-hemispherical. Intestine six ceUs in circumference; granules scattered, dark, mctallic appearing. Prerectum length four to five times body width. Rectum length equal to anal body diameter. Ovaries symmetricai, reflexed onc-half to two-thirds distance to vulva. Egg length one and one-half times body width, half as wide aslong. Vulva transverse, heavily cuticularized, Female rails hemisphcrical to bluntly conoid. Males rare, only a single one observed in Utall among over 100 females. Suppléments 1 2. rather uniformly spaced, three within range of spicula. Spicula dorylaimoid. Latéral guiding pièces tapering distally.
Habitat: A cosmopolitan species from many European countries, The Faroes and Nova Zembla. Common at élévations of 8,000 to 12,000 fect in Wasatch and Uinta Mountains, Utah, U. S. A.
Synonyms: Dorylaimus vesuvianus C obb, 1893 Dorylaimellus vesuvi&nus (C obb, 1893) T horne & S wanger, 1936

document.paragraph: Lip région low, rounded, completely amalgamated, set off by siight dépression, papillae not interfering with contour. Amphids broad, stirnip-shaped. Spear, exclusive of extension, one and one-half finies as long as lip région width. Spear extension almost twice as long as spear, the basal portion bearing flanges. Esophagus enlargcd in posterior two-fifths. Cardia hemispherical, bail as wide as esophagus base. Intestinal celte with scattered brown granules. Fcmale prerectum length about twice body width, rectum a little longer than anal body diameter. Ovaries reflexed about half way to vulva. Anterior ovary of one specimen outstrctched. Suppléments 10, rather uniformly spaced, the first within range of spicula. Spicule thick; massive. Latéral guiding pièces simple, straight. Female tail bluntly conoid, male rail rounded, only half as long as anal body diameter.
Enchodelus vesuvianus is closely related to E. macrodorus from which it differs in the proportionately longer sections of the spear extension and more rounded, lower lip région.

Above description and figures from Dr. C obb ’s original balsam preserved spécimens, two males, two females and eight young, which are now, February 1938, just as perfectly preserved as when prepared by that master technician in 1889.
Habitai: Moss collectcd on sides of Mount Vesuvius, Italy.

document.paragraph: Lip région set off by siight constriction, the lips somewhat angular. Spear length about twice width of lip région. In cross section the basal flanges of the spear extensions are symmetrically arranged (fig. 70a). Esophagus distinctly set off irom spear, enlarged ncar middle by rather sudden expansion. Lumen of intestine containing masses of green, chlorophyll-like material. Ovaries symmetrical, reflexed about half way back to vulva. Eggs one and one-half finies as long as body width and one-third as wide as long, as many as four were observed in the uteri at one time. Prerectum length two to three times body width. The blunt, dorsally convex-conoid tail usually ’ contains '10- 15 pairs of saccate bodies similar to those of Pungentus.

Diagnosis: Enchodelus with the abovc nieasuremcnts and general description. Most closcly related to E. macrodorus from which it differs in the more angular lips, mid-body location of vulva and conoid tail.
Habitat: About roots of alpine plants and moss, summit of Longs Peak, Colorado, U. S . A., élévation 14,255 ft.
Synonyms: Dorylaimellus {Doryllium) groeniandicus Ditlhvsen, 1927 Dorylaimellus groeniandicus (Ditlevsek. 2927) T horne & Swanger . 1936

document.paragraph: Similar to Enchodelus macrodorus but grcater in size: spear and flanged extensions equal in length, the basal flanges ovate in contour; esophagus slightly shorter. Ovaries short, symmetrical.
Prercctum length about four times body width. Habitai: Bank of a brook, Disco, Greenland. Reicrences: 42 , 159.

document.paragraph: Lips rather angular, set off by slight dépréssion, onc-fourth as wide as neck base. Spear length onlv one and one-half times Hp région width. Esophagus enlargcd in posterior two-ïifths by graduai expansion. Subrnedian pair of esophageal glands located about midway between dorsal gland and esophagus base. Cardia cyiindricai. Intestinal cclls with fine brown granules. Prcrectum length twice body width, rectum a little longer than anal body diameter. Ovaries synunetrical, reflexed half way to vulva, Egg length equal to one and one-half times body width, one-third as wide as long. Tail bluntly conoid with about 50 saccate bodies on each side very similar to those in Pungentus. Males unknown and gravid femaïes contained no sperms.

Diagnosis: Enchodelus with the above measurements and general description. This species is distinguished from ils closest relative, Enchodelus brevidens, by the more angular lip région and greater number of saccate caudal bodies. Described from specimens preserved in balsam.
Habitat: Seventeen females from soil about roots of alpine plants, élévation 11,295 feet, summit of Loue Peak, near Draper, Utah, U. S . A.

document.paragraph: Lip région set off by slight dépréssion, about one-fourth width of ne 4 > base, laps rounded, amalgamatcd. Amphids alrnost as vide as head, sensillae opposite spear base . Spear, exclusive of extension, as long as lip région width, the apcrturc occupying one-fourth its length. Spear extension

well cuticularizcd but not forming flanges, set off from esophagus by constriction. Esophagus cnlarged a littlc back of middle. Intestine with scattered granules in its cells, the lumen filled with green organic material. Prcrectum length about twice body width. Rectum slightly longer than anal body diameter. Ovaries long, rcfkxed two-thirds distance to vulva. Eggs not quitc twice as long as body width. Sperms in utérus indicate that males exist. About 25 pairs of saccaie bodies présent in the tail, similar to those of Pungentus.

Diagnosis: Enchodelus with the above measurements and general description. Most closcly related to
Enchodelus teres
from which il differs in shorter spear and Jess conspicuous lips.
Habitat: A single gravid femate from stream bank soil, Broad Run, near Leesburg, Virginia, U. S . A.
Synonyme: Dorylaimus [Doryllium) analatus DEtlevsek, 1927. Dorylaimellus analatus ( Ditlevsen , 1927) Thorne A Swanger, 1936. Plate IX, Fig. 74, 74«

Body tapering rapidly anteriorly. Lip région truncaic. lips indistinct, papillae tiny. Spear proper three-fourths as long as its extensions, which lack definite flanges. Esophagus at first very narrov, then éxpanding rather suddenly back of nerve ring. Intcstineat first about twice width of esophagus. Prerectum length only about equal to body diameter. Ovaries symmetrical.
Enchodelus analatus differs from E. macrodorus in the lack of basal spear flanges. very short prerectum and more tapenng neck.
Habitat: Moss, Kapisigdlit (Fjord of Godthaab), and Upcrnivjk, Groenland.
Référencés: 42 . 159.
Enchodelus conicandafus (D itlevsen, 1927)n. comb.
Synonyms: Dorylaimus conwandalus D itlevsen, 1927 Dorylaimellus conicaudalus (DITLEVSEN, 1927) T horne & S wanger, 1936

document.paragraph: Spear slender, ont and one-fourth times as long as width of lip région. Head amalgamated until

neither lips nor papillae are obvions. Esophagus slender to inconspicuous nerve ring, then increasing to about one-third neck width. An elongate, pear-shapedbody is located ventrally just back of nerve ring. Prerectum about half as long as esophagus. Tail conica! to rounded tip, varyitig in acuteuess with different specimens. Ovaries short, symmetrical.
Habitat: Moss collected at Kapisigdlk, Fjord of Godthaab, Greenland.
Référencés: 42, 159.
Synonyms: Dorylaimus macrodoroides S teiner, 1914 Dorylaimellus macrodoroides (S teiner, 1914) T horne & S wanger, 1936

Discomycius longicaudatus (Imainura), 82, head, x 200; 82«, iemale tail, X 1000. After Imamura,

document.paragraph: Lip région amalgamated, set off by slight constriction. Spear proper about two and one-half times lip région width. Extensions rather conspicuously developed but without broad flanges. Posterior two-fifths of esophagus enlarged by graduai expansion until more than half neck width. Intestinal cells with dark brown, metallic appearing granules. Prerectum length four to five times body width. Rectum almost as long as tail. Ovaries symmetrical, reflexed one-half to two-thirds the distance back to vulva. Eggs about two and one-half times as long as body diameter. Tail slightly ventrally arcuate to small blunt terminus.
The principal differentiating characters of this species are spear length and typical tail form.

Habitat: Described by S teiner (143) from wet humus, Airolo, Switzerland. A rather commun species from soil about roots of alpine plants collected on Loue Peak, Mt. Timpanogos, Devils Castle, Mt. Deseret and other mountain peaks in Utah, U. S . A. One female in Dr. C obb 's collection from Casa Poëtae, Pompeii, Italy.
Synonyms: Dorylaimus (Doryllium} jaeroensis D hievsek, 1928 Dorylaimellus jaeroensis (D itlevsen, I 928 j T horne & S wanger, 1936

Body tapering rapidly at both extremities. Lips obscure, set off by slight dépréssion. Two cirelets of easily visible papillac. Spear, inciuding extensions, equa] to about one-third neck length. Basal flanges of spear narrow. Prerectum length about two and one-half times body width. Tail ventrally arcuatc. Terminus subacute.
Enchodelus faeroensis is distinctive because of the obscurely set off lip région, relatively more tapering extremities, short prerectum and greater body length.
Habitat: Svino, short of the larger of the two lakes south of Mannaskard, Faroe Islands.
Référencés: 43, 159.

Transverse striae rather coarse. Lips low, rounded, amalgamated, set off by slight dépréssion. Amphids wide and deep. Spear length, exclusive of extension, onc and one-half times lip région width. Spear extension and muscles surrounding it conspicuous but not fonning Ranges. Esophagus enlarged by graduai expansion just back of middie. Three esophagcal gland nuclei easily seen. Cardia elongate-hemispherical. Intestinal colis with fine brown granules. Rectum about as long as tail. Prerectum twicç length of rectum. Ovaries long, rcflexed about half way to vulva. Egg length one and one-third times body width. Tail conoid arcuate to small blunt terminus.

DmgMiWîs: Enchodelus with the above measurcmems and general description. Most ciosely' related to E. nuicrodoroidcs and E. brevidentatus, differing in the form of lip région and relative proportions of spear. Above formula frorn gravid Virginia specimens . Thosc from Arizona and Utah attaineti a length of 2 inm, vulva of Arizona females at 48%, tail a little more slender than lhat figured from Virginia.
Habitat: One fcmale from soil, pine woods, Arlington Farm, Virginia, two from Kaibab Forest, Arizona, and three from sod, Tryal Lake, Uinta Mountains, Utah, U . S. A.
